title: Isaiah Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 17.

questions.question: What will happen to Damascus according to Isaiah 17:1?
options: It will be taken away and become a ruinous heap
It will become the capital of Israel
It will be surrounded by armies
It will prosper and multiply
questions.correctAnswer: It will be taken away and become a ruinous heap
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:1 states that Damascus is taken away from being a city and shall be a ruinous heap.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 17:2, what will the cities of Aroer become?
options: Places forsaken and for flocks to lie down without fear
Strongholds for armies
Centers of trade and commerce
Places of worship
questions.correctAnswer: Places forsaken and for flocks to lie down without fear
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:2 describes the cities of Aroer as forsaken and places for flocks to lie down without being afraid.

questions.question: What shall cease from Ephraim and Damascus according to Isaiah 17:3?
options: The fortress and the kingdom
The harvest and the trade
The worship and the festivals
The kingship and the priests
questions.correctAnswer: The fortress and the kingdom
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:3 states that the fortress shall cease from Ephraim and the kingdom from Damascus.

questions.question: What will happen to the glory of Jacob in Isaiah 17:4?
options: It shall be made thin and the fatness of his flesh shall wax lean
It shall be multiplied and flourish
It shall be hidden in the mountains
It shall be taken to a foreign land
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be made thin and the fatness of his flesh shall wax lean
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:4 says the glory of Jacob will be made thin and the fatness of his flesh will become lean.

questions.question: In Isaiah 17:5, the harvestman is compared to gathering what?
options: Corn and ears with his arm
Grapes and olives
Wheat and barley
Fruits and vegetables
questions.correctAnswer: Corn and ears with his arm
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:5 compares the harvestman gathering corn and reaping ears with his arm.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 17:6, how many grapes may remain after gleaning?
options: Two or three berries in the top of the uppermost bough
None at all
Ten or more
Only one on the lowest branch
questions.correctAnswer: Two or three berries in the top of the uppermost bough
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:6 describes that two or three berries remain in the top of the uppermost bough after gleaning.

questions.question: What will a man do at that day according to Isaiah 17:7?
options: Look to his Maker and have respect to the Holy One of Israel
Build new altars
Worship idols
Flee from his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Look to his Maker and have respect to the Holy One of Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:7 states that at that day a man shall look to his Maker and respect the Holy One of Israel.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 17:8, what shall he not look to?
options: Altars, groves, or images made by his hands
His neighbors
The sun or moon
The mountains
questions.correctAnswer: Altars, groves, or images made by his hands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:8 says he shall not look to altars or images made by his hands.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 17:9 says that strong cities will be as a forsaken bough with desolation.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:9 describes strong cities as forsaken boughs and mentions desolation.

questions.question: Why does Isaiah 17:10 say one will plant pleasant plants and set strange slips?
options: Because they have forgotten the God of their salvation and the rock of their strength
Because it is the season for planting
Because the land is fertile
Because of a command from the king
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have forgotten the God of their salvation and the rock of their strength
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:10 explains that planting strange slips comes from forgetting God and not being mindful of strength.

questions.question: What will happen to the harvest according to Isaiah 17:11?
options: It will be a heap in the day of grief and desperate sorrow
It will be abundant and plentiful
It will be shared with neighbors
It will be stored for many years
questions.correctAnswer: It will be a heap in the day of grief and desperate sorrow
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:11 says the harvest will be a heap in the day of grief and desperate sorrow.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 17:12 compares the noise of many people to the noise of the seas.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:12 states woe to the multitude of many people making noise like the seas.

questions.question: What will God do to the nations that rush like many waters in Isaiah 17:13?
options: Rebuke them so they flee far off and are chased like chaff
Join them in battle
Ignore them
Bless them with peace
questions.correctAnswer: Rebuke them so they flee far off and are chased like chaff
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:13 says God shall rebuke the rushing nations and they will flee and be chased like chaff.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 17:14: 'And behold at eveningtide _______; and before the morning he is not.'
options: trouble
peace
joy
victory
questions.correctAnswer: trouble
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:14 states, 'And behold at eveningtide trouble; and before the morning he is not.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 17:14 mentions the portion of those who spoil and rob as lasting forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:14 indicates that trouble comes at evening and is gone by morning, not lasting forever.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Isaiah 17, what biblical truth about trusting God would you share?
options: Trust in the LORD, even when cities and kingdoms fall
Rely on human strength and alliances
Worship altars and images made by hands
Focus on earthly riches and harvests
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the LORD, even when cities and kingdoms fall
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:1-3 shows the fall of Damascus and Ephraim, yet verse 7 encourages looking to the Maker and Holy One of Israel amidst trials, teaching reliance on God rather than earthly powers.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 17 teach us about humility and dependence on God in times of loss or desolation?
options: Man will look to his Maker and respect the Holy One
Man will build stronger altars with his own hands
Man will trust in his own strength and plant strange slips
Man will seek riches to overcome sorrow
questions.correctAnswer: Man will look to his Maker and respect the Holy One
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:7-8 explains that in the day of hardship, people will look to God rather than idols, showing humility and dependence on God rather than self or false security.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to rely on idols or man-made objects for security. According to Isaiah 17, what should you advise?
options: Do not look to altars or images made by hands
Increase offerings to idols for protection
Build more impressive temples
Trust in political alliances
questions.correctAnswer: Do not look to altars or images made by hands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:8 warns against looking to altars or images made by human hands, emphasizing reliance on God alone for true security.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 17 teach about the consequences of forgetting God and being unmindful of His strength?
options: Planting pleasant plants will fail and harvest will bring grief
Success and abundance will increase
Peace and safety will be guaranteed
Idols will protect the land
questions.correctAnswer: Planting pleasant plants will fail and harvest will bring grief
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:10-11 explains that forgetting God leads to futile efforts and sorrowful harvests, teaching the importance of remembering and trusting God’s strength.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 17 instruct believers to respond when facing overwhelming opposition or ‘mighty waters’?
options: Trust that God will rebuke the nations and scatter them
Fight aggressively to defend territory
Form alliances with stronger nations
Ignore God and rely on self
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God will rebuke the nations and scatter them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:12-13 teaches that although nations rush like mighty waters, God will rebuke and scatter them, encouraging believers to trust God’s deliverance in trials.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged because their efforts seem wasted. Based on Isaiah 17, what biblical truth about perseverance and trust would you share?
options: Though harvest may seem like a heap of grief, God's judgment will come
Give up because efforts are meaningless
Rely on idols for success
Ignore God and depend solely on human effort
questions.correctAnswer: Though harvest may seem like a heap of grief, God's judgment will come
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:11 and 14 reveal that while efforts may result in sorrow, God’s justice prevails, teaching perseverance and trust in God’s timing.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 17 emphasize the importance of spiritual discernment in worship?
options: Reject worship of altars and images made by hands
Create new images for worship
Follow traditions without questioning
Depend on physical objects for holiness
questions.correctAnswer: Reject worship of altars and images made by hands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:8 clearly instructs against looking to altars or images made by human hands, teaching believers to worship God in spirit and truth.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 17 assures that even if cities and kingdoms fall, those who look to God will find hope and restoration.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 1-3 describe destruction, but verse 7 shows that looking to God brings hope, teaching that faith in God sustains believers through loss.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 17 encourages planting strange slips and relying on one's own strength rather than God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:10-11 condemns forgetting God and relying on strange plants, illustrating the futility of trusting human strength over God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "At that day shall a man look to his ________, and his eyes shall have respect to the Holy One of Israel."
options: Maker
King
Priest
Prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Maker
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:7 teaches that in times of distress, people will look to their Maker, emphasizing reliance on God as Creator and Savior.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 17 illustrate the principle of contentment and gratitude in the face of scarcity?
options: Even a few grapes or olives remain, showing God’s provision
All fruit is completely lost
Wealth will always increase
People will steal from neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: Even a few grapes or olives remain, showing God’s provision
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:6 describes a few berries left on the olive tree and grapes, symbolizing God’s ongoing provision and encouraging gratitude even in hardship.

questions.question: What lesson about prayer and seeking God’s help can we learn from the imagery of rushing nations in Isaiah 17?
options: Trust God to rebuke and scatter overwhelming forces
Rely on human armies alone
Avoid prayer since it’s ineffective
Make alliances with stronger nations
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to rebuke and scatter overwhelming forces
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:12-13 shows that despite the noise and rush of nations, God rebukes and scatters them, teaching believers to trust God’s power through prayer.

questions.question: In family life, what biblical truth about integrity and trustworthiness does Isaiah 17 convey through its warnings against idolatry?
options: Trust and honor God alone rather than false objects
Use idols to gain favor
Trust only in family traditions
Ignore God’s commandments
questions.correctAnswer: Trust and honor God alone rather than false objects
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:8 warns against respecting altars and images, encouraging families to build integrity by honoring God alone.

questions.question: How can Isaiah 17 encourage believers to maintain a faithful work ethic during difficult times?
options: Work diligently even if the harvest seems small or sorrowful
Give up when results are poor
Rely on luck for success
Ignore God in business affairs
questions.correctAnswer: Work diligently even if the harvest seems small or sorrowful
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:11 acknowledges the sorrow of a poor harvest but implies the importance of continuing to work faithfully with trust in God.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 17 teach about God’s justice toward those who spoil and rob His people?
options: They will face trouble at evening and be gone before morning
They will prosper forever
God will ignore their actions
They will be honored publicly
questions.correctAnswer: They will face trouble at evening and be gone before morning
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:14 states that those who spoil and rob will face sudden judgment, teaching believers about God’s righteous justice.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 17.

questions.question: What is the fate of Damascus as described in Isaiah 17:1?
options: It will become a ruinous heap
It will be a flourishing city
It will be conquered but remain intact
It will be turned into a desert
questions.correctAnswer: It will become a ruinous heap
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:1 states that Damascus is taken away from being a city and shall be a ruinous heap, indicating complete destruction.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 17:2, what will the cities of Aroer become?
options: Places for flocks to lie down unafraid
Strong military fortresses
Centers of trade and commerce
Sacred religious sites
questions.correctAnswer: Places for flocks to lie down unafraid
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:2 describes the cities of Aroer as forsaken and destined to be for flocks to lie down, with none to make them afraid, symbolizing desolation and peace for animals rather than humans.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 17:3 imply about the kingdom of Damascus and the remnant of Syria?
options: They will cease as a fortress and kingdom
They will be strengthened by the LORD
They will expand their territory
They will form an alliance with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They will cease as a fortress and kingdom
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that the fortress shall cease from Ephraim, and the kingdom from Damascus, indicating an end to their political and military power.

questions.question: Isaiah 17:4 uses the image of the 'glory of Jacob' becoming thin. What literary device is primarily used here?
options: Metaphor
Simile
Hyperbole
Personification
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: The 'glory of Jacob' being made thin and the fatness of his flesh waxing lean in Isaiah 17:4 is a metaphor for Israel's diminishing prosperity and strength.

questions.question: In Isaiah 17:5, the harvestman gathering corn with his arm is an example of what kind of imagery?
options: Agricultural imagery symbolizing judgment
Military imagery symbolizing conquest
Religious imagery symbolizing sacrifice
Architectural imagery symbolizing strength
questions.correctAnswer: Agricultural imagery symbolizing judgment
questions.explanation: The harvest imagery in verse 5 symbolizes the thoroughness of judgment, like a reaper gathering every ear of corn.

questions.question: What does the mention of 'gleaning grapes' and 'shaking of an olive tree' in Isaiah 17:6 symbolize?
options: The remnant left after judgment
Abundant blessing and prosperity
A complete harvest without leftovers
The destruction of agricultural produce
questions.correctAnswer: The remnant left after judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:6 uses the imagery of a few grapes and olives left after shaking the tree to symbolize a small remnant surviving divine judgment.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 17:7, what change will occur in the people's perspective on their Maker?
options: They will look to their Maker and respect the Holy One of Israel
They will reject their Maker and worship idols
They will forget their Maker entirely
They will only respect altars and images
questions.correctAnswer: They will look to their Maker and respect the Holy One of Israel
questions.explanation: Verse 7 foretells a day when people will turn their eyes to God, the Holy One of Israel, indicating repentance and renewed faith.

questions.question: Isaiah 17:8 warns against looking to what instead of the Maker?
options: Altars, groves, and images made by hands
The heavens and stars
Foreign kings and nations
The temple sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Altars, groves, and images made by hands
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states that people shall not look to altars, groves, or images which are the work of human hands, highlighting idolatry's futility.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 17:9 says, 'In that day shall his strong cities be as a ______ bough, and an uppermost branch.'
options: forsaken
fruitful
mighty
flourishing
questions.correctAnswer: forsaken
questions.explanation: The term 'forsaken' describes the state of strong cities abandoned and desolate, as stated in Isaiah 17:9.

questions.question: What reason does Isaiah 17:10 give for the coming desolation?
options: Forgetting the God of salvation and not remembering the rock of strength
Attacking neighboring nations
Building pagan altars
Ignoring the prophets of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Forgetting the God of salvation and not remembering the rock of strength
questions.explanation: Verse 10 directly links the planting of strange slips and eventual grief to forgetting God, the rock of strength.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 17:11 predict about the harvest despite initial growth?
options: The harvest shall become a heap in the day of grief and desperate sorrow
The harvest will be abundant and joyous
The harvest will be stolen by enemies
The harvest will be delayed until next year
questions.correctAnswer: The harvest shall become a heap in the day of grief and desperate sorrow
questions.explanation: The verse contrasts the promising growth of plants with a harvest that turns to a heap amid grief, symbolizing disappointment and calamity.

questions.question: Isaiah 17:12 uses the metaphor of many people making noise like what?
options: The noise of the seas
The roar of lions
The thunder of storms
The sound of trumpets
questions.correctAnswer: The noise of the seas
questions.explanation: The verse compares the tumultuous noise of many peoples and nations to the roaring seas, emphasizing chaotic and overwhelming forces.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 17:13, how will God deal with the rushing nations?
options: He shall rebuke them and they shall flee far off
He will join them in their conquest
He will remain silent
He will bless them
questions.correctAnswer: He shall rebuke them and they shall flee far off
questions.explanation: Verse 13 describes God rebuking the rushing nations causing them to flee like chaff before the wind, illustrating divine judgment.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the phrase in Isaiah 17:14, 'At eveningtide trouble; and before the morning he is not'?
options: The enemies' downfall will be sudden and complete
Trouble will last all night
Morning will bring more trouble
The people will be cursed forever
questions.correctAnswer: The enemies' downfall will be sudden and complete
questions.explanation: This phrase signifies the swift destruction of those who spoil and rob, indicating their sudden disappearance by morning.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 17:7-8 shows a shift from idolatry to worshiping the Holy One of Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 7 and 8 contrast looking to the Maker and Holy One of Israel with rejecting altars and images, indicating a shift from idolatry to true worship.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 17:1 declare will happen to Damascus?
options: It will become a ruinous heap
It will flourish and prosper
It will be a strong fortress
It will be a peaceful city
questions.correctAnswer: It will become a ruinous heap
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:1 states that Damascus will be taken away from being a city and become a ruinous heap, indicating divine judgment and desolation. This is consistent with other prophetic judgments such as in Jeremiah 49:23-27 where Damascus is also foretold to face destruction, and Ezekiel 27:17 which speaks of the fall of cities. The theme reflects God's sovereignty over nations (Psalm 2:1-4) and His role as judge (Romans 1:18-20).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 17:3, what will cease from Ephraim and Damascus?
options: The fortress and the kingdom
The worship and the sacrifices
The vineyards and the fields
The alliances and treaties
questions.correctAnswer: The fortress and the kingdom
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:3 declares that the fortress from Ephraim and the kingdom from Damascus shall cease, illustrating the removal of political and military power. This aligns with God's judgment on earthly powers in Daniel 2:44 where God's kingdom replaces worldly kingdoms, and Zechariah 9:10 which speaks of the end of war. It highlights God's sovereignty over political realms (Colossians 1:16).

questions.question: What imagery is used in Isaiah 17:5 to describe the devastation of Israel's land?
options: The harvestman gathereth the corn and reapeth ears
The vineyard is full of wild beasts
The olive tree is cut down to its roots
The river dries up and the fish perish
questions.correctAnswer: The harvestman gathereth the corn and reapeth ears
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:5 uses the metaphor of a harvestman gathering and reaping ears of corn to symbolize thorough devastation and removal of sustenance. This agricultural imagery conveys judgment and loss, similar to Joel 1:10-12 where harvest is described as destroyed, and Jeremiah 12:10 where vineyards are laid waste. It points to consequences of sin and God's judgment (Romans 6:23).

questions.question: In Isaiah 17:7, what change occurs in a man's focus on that day?
options: He will look to his Maker and have respect to the Holy One of Israel
He will turn away from God and worship idols
He will seek alliances with foreign nations
He will rely on his own strength
questions.correctAnswer: He will look to his Maker and have respect to the Holy One of Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:7 reveals a spiritual awakening where a man turns his eyes to God, acknowledging Him as Maker and Holy One. This reflects repentance and faith, consistent with Acts 17:27 where God is sought by all, and Psalm 46:10 urging to know God as sovereign. It highlights God’s holiness and man’s need for divine grace (Hebrews 12:28-29).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 17:8, what will a man no longer look to or respect?
options: Altars, groves, and images made by human hands
The laws of men and their traditions
The wisdom of the elders and the prophets
The wealth and power of nations
questions.correctAnswer: Altars, groves, and images made by human hands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:8 states that the man will not look to altars or idols made by his own hands, indicating a rejection of idolatry. This aligns with the First Commandment (Exodus 20:4-5) and the New Testament condemnation of idolatry (1 Corinthians 10:14). It emphasizes God’s requirement for exclusive worship and the futility of idols (Psalm 115:4-8).

questions.question: What reason does Isaiah 17:10 give for Israel planting pleasant plants and strange slips?
options: Because they forgot God and were not mindful of their strength
Because they sought to expand their territory
Because they desired to honor their ancestors
Because they wanted to trade with other nations
questions.correctAnswer: Because they forgot God and were not mindful of their strength
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:10 explains that the planting of pleasant plants and strange slips is due to forgetting God and not remembering the rock of their strength. This shows human reliance on worldly means rather than divine provision, similar to Hosea 2:8 and Jeremiah 2:13 where forsaking God leads to futility. It underscores the doctrine of human sinfulness and the need for dependence on God (John 15:5).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 17:12 describe the multitude of people and nations?
options: They make noise like the seas and rush like mighty waters
They march quietly and steadily like a gentle stream
They are scattered like dust in the wind
They stand firm like ancient mountains
questions.correctAnswer: They make noise like the seas and rush like mighty waters
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:12 compares the multitude of people and nations to noisy seas and rushing mighty waters, symbolizing overwhelming and chaotic forces. This imagery recurs in Revelation 17:15 and Psalm 93:3-4, representing tumultuous human powers opposed to God. It reflects eschatological themes of nations rising against God’s people (Psalm 2:1-3).

questions.question: What is the fate of the nations described in Isaiah 17:13?
options: God shall rebuke them, and they shall flee far off like chaff before the wind
They shall conquer and establish their kingdoms
They shall form lasting peace treaties
They shall be exalted above Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God shall rebuke them, and they shall flee far off like chaff before the wind
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:13 prophesies that despite their power, the nations will be rebuked by God and scattered like chaff, showing divine sovereignty over the nations. This is echoed in Psalm 1:4, Matthew 3:12, and Revelation 14:14-20 where God's judgment disperses the wicked. It emphasizes God's ultimate control and judgment over rebellious powers.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 17:14 reveal about the duration of trouble for those who spoil and rob Israel?
options: Trouble comes in the evening and they are gone before morning
Trouble lasts for many years
Trouble is constant without relief
Trouble happens only once a decade
questions.correctAnswer: Trouble comes in the evening and they are gone before morning
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:14 describes that trouble will come suddenly and swiftly, like evening trouble that disappears before morning, signifying God's quick and decisive judgment. This is consistent with 1 Thessalonians 5:2-3 and Luke 21:34-36 describing sudden divine intervention. It assures believers of God’s protection and justice.

questions.question: What does the term 'glory of Jacob shall be made thin' in Isaiah 17:4 signify theologically?
options: The diminishing of Israel’s prosperity and strength due to judgment
The expansion of Israel’s territory
The increase in Israel’s spiritual vitality
The restoration of Israel’s covenant blessings
questions.correctAnswer: The diminishing of Israel’s prosperity and strength due to judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:4 uses 'glory of Jacob made thin' to depict the weakening and loss of Israel’s former honor and blessing because of sin and judgment. This fits with Deuteronomy 28:15-46 where disobedience leads to curses, and Romans 11:17-21 which warns against falling from grace. It illustrates the consequences of unfaithfulness to God.

questions.question: Isaiah 17:6 mentions 'gleaning grapes' left as when shaking an olive tree. What does this symbolize?
options: A remnant preserved despite judgment
Complete destruction with no survivors
Abundance and prosperity
The growth of idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: A remnant preserved despite judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:6’s imagery of a few grapes left after harvest symbolizes a remnant spared from total destruction, a common biblical theme (Romans 11:5, Zephaniah 3:13). It reflects God's mercy and faithfulness to preserve a faithful remnant for restoration (Isaiah 10:20-22).

questions.question: In Isaiah 17:9, what is the condition of strong cities described as?
options: Forsaken boughs and uppermost branches left behind
Fortresses impregnable and full of life
Centers of worship and peace
Strongholds of justice and mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Forsaken boughs and uppermost branches left behind
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:9 compares strong cities to forsaken boughs and branches left behind, indicating abandonment and desolation due to God's judgment. This imagery parallels Hosea 9:16 and Jeremiah 9:17 where Israel’s protection is withdrawn. It teaches the consequence of forsaking God’s covenant (Psalm 37:38).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 17:11, what will be the result of planting and flourishing in the day?
options: The harvest will become a heap in the day of grief and sorrow
The crops will yield plentifully in due season
The plants will grow strong and fruitful
The fields will be blessed and prosperous
questions.correctAnswer: The harvest will become a heap in the day of grief and sorrow
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:11 states that though planting and seed flourishing occur, the harvest will result in a heap during a day of grief, symbolizing futility and divine judgment. This correlates with Jeremiah 8:13 and Hosea 9:1 where harvests become cursed due to sin. It illustrates the consequences of ignoring God’s salvation.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'the rock of thy strength' in Isaiah 17:10?
options: It refers to God as the foundation and strength of Israel
It refers to the mountains surrounding Israel
It refers to the king of Israel
It refers to the temple altar
questions.correctAnswer: It refers to God as the foundation and strength of Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:10’s phrase 'rock of thy strength' is a metaphor for God as Israel’s dependable foundation, consistent with Deuteronomy 32:4, Psalm 18:2, and 1 Corinthians 10:4. It emphasizes God’s unchanging nature and the futility of forgetting Him. This doctrine is central to biblical theology about God’s steadfastness.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 17:2 describe the cities of Aroer after judgment?
options: They shall be for flocks that lie down without fear
They shall be fortified and defended
They shall be centers of idol worship
They shall be bustling trade hubs
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be for flocks that lie down without fear
questions.explanation: Isaiah 17:2 says the cities of Aroer will be forsaken and become pastures for flocks that rest without fear, illustrating desolation and the absence of human habitation. This echoes Ezekiel 34:27 and Jeremiah 50:39 where desolated places become grazing lands. It symbolizes God’s judgment and the reversal of human dominion.
